awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase II: A Spectroscopic THz Sensor for Mixed Gas Analysis and Air Pollution Monitoring
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project is to create an economical, light‐weight, high performance Terahertz (THz) spectrometer to allow testing of air and fossil fuels for the presence of harmful compounds. A frequency domain THz spectrometer is capable of characterizing the different molecules and chemicals in a gas sample. Historically these spectrometers have been relegated to the laboratory because of their size and complexity but recent technical advancements have made it possible to build a spectroscopic THz sensor small enough and light enough to be flown on a consumer drone. The reductions in size and cost have opened the door to using THz sensors for emissions testing of ships entering U.S. waters or contaminant testing of fossil fuels at petroleum processing facilities. This is significant because the ability to analyze samples locally removes the time and expense of collecting and shipping potentially dangerous compounds (i.e. flammable compounds or pollutants) to a laboratory for analysis. It also allows detection and classification to occur on short notice and without the need to subject personnel to the local environment. 

The proposed project will produce the first article of a compact, battery operated, autonomously operating spectroscopic THz sensor capable of mixed gas analysis to parts per million sensitivities. It will be constructed predominantly from economical off‐the‐shelf fiber optic components in a novel highly compact, light‐weight form factor. In order to achieve the high sensitivities, the spectroscopic THz sensor will incorporate: high fidelity lasers from the telecommunications industry, custom designed and fabricated high efficiency, hermetically sealed photomixers, a folded, light‐weight, carbon fiber sample cell incorporating patented 3D printed mirror technology and a patented optical phase‐modulation technique that removes the effects of coherent detection. The instrument will first be employed for laboratory based measurements of sulfur-containing contaminants in gas flows. Upon the successful demonstration of the capabilities of the instrument, a first article will be used in initial testing and collaborative field work. Sales of a larger laboratory instrument based on the same technology will begin simultaneously.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of our National Science Foundation Project titled "A Spectroscopic THz Sensor for Mixed Gas Analysis and Air Pollution Monitoring" was to bring a THz technology to market that would detect illegal emissions and help with the enforcement of air pollution standards. We envisioned a drone mounted spectroscopic THz sensor for performing spot emissions testing on ships entering U.S. waters to ensure that they promptly switched from bunker fuel to low-sulfur diesel. Terahertz (THz) spectroscopy is a practical tool for gas analysis because rotational transitions for a large variety of molecules occur in this frequency domain.  These transitions are very specific to each molecule and may be used to measure the presence and concentration of different molecules in a gas sample.  Only compounds with a dipole moment will absorb THz radiation so THz spectroscopy is particularly well suited for detecting sulfuric compounds in large vehicle emissions and thereby determine if they are utilizing low-sulfur diesel.

The primary challenge of employing THz spectroscopy for sensing has been the instrument cost followed closely by sensitivity and novelty.

To address instrument cost, Bakman developed and manufactured lost cost electronics that can be operated with a Raspberry Pi or similar; that will allow the use of any manufacturer?s butterfly packaged laser; that has a footprint of only 195 mm x 195 mm; that incorporates a two channel, high dynamic range lock-in amplifier; and that has multiple end uses besides that of THz spectroscopy.  We also focused on developing an instrument using telecommunication devices which operate at wavelengths around 1550 nm since these devices are produced in large quantities.  This Bakman development resulted in a THz instrument that at one hundred piece volumes will cost less than $20,000.

Several factors impact system sensitivity, the most easily addressed being sample depth of thickness.  There is a 1:1 correspondence between path-length and sensitivity: increasing sample path-length by 10x results in a 10x increase in sensitivity.  Frequency domain THz spectrometers typically incorporate a 10 cm path-length between the source and the detector.  Under this NSF funding Bakman developed two separate types of multi-pass sample cells which increase this path-length to almost 5 meters. One of these multi-pass cells is now the Bakman Technologies PB8300-050 White Cell and is for sale as a standard product. The second multi-pass cell, termed a Shared Focus Sample Cell (SFSC), is currently patent-applied-for. The SFSC is unusual because all the optical beams come to a focus in the center of the cell.  This extends its potential usefulness to the measurement of small solid samples, not just gases.  Additionally, Bakman developed the techniques and tooling needed to manufacture the White Cell and SFCS optics in-house, significantly curtailing cost.

Sensitivity can also be increased by averaging the data from multiple scans.  As with path-length, the signal-to-noise ratio increases 1:1 with the number of scans averaged.  Bakman has developed a method for high-speed scanning and averaging that is being incorporated into our new instruments.

It is difficult to convince potential customers in new markets that a novel product such as a ?Spectroscopic THz Sensor? is right for their application. Besides focusing on specific sensing applications and manufacturing a sensor that is better and less expensive than what is available, it is also necessary to make THz technology more familiar. In order to do our small part towards this, we have focused on interesting marketing such as YouTube videos of "THz Drones" and catchy Newswise.com articles like: "THz Spectrometers: 'Ford vs. Ferrari'", "The Jackson Pollock of THz Photomixing" and "Will This Be the Face of 7G?" This is only a small step towards garnering the interest of new markets. The work will need to continue and care will need to be taken not to miss-step with any opportunities to demonstrate spectroscopic THz sensors in potential markets.

At the conclusion of this NSF program, we have fully developed and manufactured a smaller, low cost Spectroscopic THz Sensor that weighs less than 4.5 kg, operates from a Raspberry Pi, can be operated in a fixed location or from a drone and will detect various compounds of atmospheric interest including hydrogen sulfide.
